title: What is a permutation of a set? - Quora

response.answer_text: A permutation of a set [math]X[/math] is a function which maps [math]X[/math] to itself in a one-to-one (injective) and onto (surjective) fashion. For example, if [math]X = \{ a, b, c \}[/math], then there are exactly six permutations of [math]X[/math]. One of them is the identity function [math]a \mapsto a, b \mapsto b, c \mapsto c[/math]. I leave it to you to write down the remaining five. If [math]X = \mathbb{N}[/math], then there are [math]2^{\aleph_0}[/math] permutations of [math]X[/math]. I wouldn't try to write all of these down if I were you.

A permutation of a set is a rearrangement of the set elements. For example, [math](2 1 3 4)[/math] is a permutation of [math](1 2 3 4)[/math]. One of the easiest ways to formalize the idea of a permutation is to define a permutation of a set to be any bijection from the set to itself.
